5. Dimension and Coordinates

5.1 Bases and Dimension

Theorem 5.1.3

Every subspace S of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn has a basis.

Finding the basis for a subspace

Let S be a subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn. To find a basis for S:

  1. Using the definition of S, find vectors v⃗1,...,v⃗k\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}v1​,...,vk​ in S such that every vector x⃗∈S\vec{x}\in\mathbb{S}x∈S can be expressed as a linear combination of v⃗1,...,v⃗k.\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}.v1​,...,vk​.
  2. Check if B={v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}B={v1​,...,vk​} is linearly independent. If it is, then stop as B\mathcal{B}B is a basis.
  3. If B\mathcal{B}B is linearly dependent, pick some vector v⃗i∈B\vec{v}_{i}\in\mathcal{B}vi​∈B that can be written as a linear combination of the other vectors in B\mathcal{B}B and remove it from the set. Repeat this until the set is linearly independent.

e.g. Find a basis for the subspace S={[a−ba−cc−b]∣a,b,c∈R}S=\{[\begin{matrix}a-b\\ a-c\\ c-b\end{matrix}]|a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}\}S={[a−ba−cc−b​]∣a,b,c∈R} of R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3. A vector in S can be written as: [a−ba−cc−b]=a[110]+b[−10−1]+c[0−11]\begin{bmatrix}a-b\\ a-c\\ c-b\end{bmatrix} = a\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 0\end{bmatrix} + b\begin{bmatrix}-1\\ 0\\ -1\end{bmatrix} + c\begin{bmatrix}0\\ -1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}​a−ba−cc−b​​=a​110​​+b​−10−1​​+c​0−11​​. Let v⃗1=[110]\vec{v}_1 = \begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}v1​=​110​​, v⃗2=[−10−1]\vec{v}_2 = \begin{bmatrix}-1\\ 0\\ -1\end{bmatrix}v2​=​−10−1​​, v⃗3=[0−11]\vec{v}_3 = \begin{bmatrix}0\\ -1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}v3​=​0−11​​. So S=Span{v⃗1,v⃗2,v⃗3}S = \text{Span}\{\vec{v}_1, \vec{v}_2, \vec{v}_3\}S=Span{v1​,v2​,v3​}. To check for linear independence, form a matrix with these vectors as columns and row reduce: [1−1010−10−11]→R2−R1[1−1001−10−11]→R1+R2,R3+R2[10−101−1000]\begin{bmatrix}1&-1&0\\ 1&0&-1\\ 0&-1&1\end{bmatrix} \xrightarrow{R_2-R_1} \begin{bmatrix}1&-1&0\\ 0&1&-1\\ 0&-1&1\end{bmatrix} \xrightarrow{R_1+R_2, R_3+R_2} \begin{bmatrix}1&0&-1\\ 0&1&-1\\ 0&0&0\end{bmatrix}​110​−10−1​0−11​​R2​−R1​​​100​−11−1​0−11​​R1​+R2​,R3​+R2​​​100​010​−1−10​​ The RREF shows that there are two pivot columns (first and second). Thus, v⃗1\vec{v}_1v1​ and v⃗2\vec{v}_2v2​ form a basis for S. From the RREF, c1v⃗1+c2v⃗2+c3v⃗3=0⃗c_1\vec{v}_1 + c_2\vec{v}_2 + c_3\vec{v}_3 = \vec{0}c1​v1​+c2​v2​+c3​v3​=0 implies c1−c3=0c_1-c_3=0c1​−c3​=0 and c2−c3=0c_2-c_3=0c2​−c3​=0. If c3=1c_3=1c3​=1, then c1=1,c2=1c_1=1, c_2=1c1​=1,c2​=1. So 1v⃗1+1v⃗2+(−1)v⃗3=0⃗1\vec{v}_1+1\vec{v}_2+ (-1)\vec{v}_3 = \vec{0}1v1​+1v2​+(−1)v3​=0 (if we write it as c1v⃗1+c2v⃗2=v⃗3c_1\vec{v}_1+c_2\vec{v}_2 = \vec{v}_3c1​v1​+c2​v2​=v3​). v⃗3=(−1)v⃗1+(−1)v⃗2\vec{v}_3 = (-1)\vec{v}_1 + (-1)\vec{v}_2v3​=(−1)v1​+(−1)v2​. Checking: (−1)[110]+(−1)[−10−1]=[−1−10]+[101]=[0−11]=v⃗3(-1)\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\0\end{bmatrix} + (-1)\begin{bmatrix}-1\\0\\-1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}-1\\-1\\0\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}0\\-1\\1\end{bmatrix} = \vec{v}_3(−1)​110​​+(−1)​−10−1​​=​−1−10​​+​101​​=​0−11​​=v3​. This is correct. So, v⃗1\vec{v}_1v1​ and v⃗2\vec{v}_2v2​ make out the basis for S. Basis for S: {[110],[−10−1]}\{ \begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\\ 0\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}-1\\ 0\\ -1\end{bmatrix} \}{​110​​,​−10−1​​}.

Theorem 5.1.7

Let S be a subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn. Let B={v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}B={v1​,...,vk​} be a basis for S and let C={w⃗1,...,w⃗m}\mathcal{C}=\{\vec{w}_{1},...,\vec{w}_{m}\}C={w1​,...,wm​} be a set in S. If m>km>km>k then C is linearly dependent. Note: Keep in mind that a basis is a minimal spanning set and a maximal linearly independent set.

Theorem 5.1.8

If B={v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}B={v1​,...,vk​} and C={w⃗1,...,w⃗m}\mathcal{C}=\{\vec{w}_{1},...,\vec{w}_{m}\}C={w1​,...,wm​} are bases for S, then k=mk=mk=m.

Let S be a subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn. If B={v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}B={v1​,...,vk​} is a basis for S, then we say the dimension of S is k and write dim S=k.\text{dim S}=k.dim S=k. If S={0⃗}\mathbb{S}=\{\vec{0}\}S={0} is the trivial subspace, then dimS=0\text{dim}\mathbb{S}=0dimS=0. (Notice that this agrees with the fact that a basis for S is the empty set.)

Theorem 5.1.12

If dim S = k, then:

  1. A set of more than k vectors in S must be linearly dependent.
  2. A set of fewer than k vectors in S cannot span S.
  3. A set of k vectors in S is linearly independent if and only if it spans S.

Theorem 5.1.15

If S is an k-dimensional subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn and {v⃗1,...,v⃗l}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{l}\}{v1​,...,vl​} is a linearly independent set in S with l<kl<kl<k, then there exist vectors w⃗l+1,...,w⃗k\vec{w}_{l+1},...,\vec{w}_{k}wl+1​,...,wk​ in S such that {v⃗1,...,v⃗l,w⃗l+1,...,w⃗k}\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{l},\vec{w}_{l+1},...,\vec{w}_{k}\}{v1​,...,vl​,wl+1​,...,wk​} is a basis for S.

Theorem 5.1.16

Let S1\mathbb{S}{1}S1 and S2\mathbb{S}{2}S2 be subspaces of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn such that S1⊆S2\mathbb{S}{1}\subseteq\mathbb{S}{2}S1⊆S2. Then dim S1≤dimS2\mathbb{S}{1}\le \text{dim}\mathbb{S}{2}S1≤dimS2. Moreover, S1=S2\mathbb{S}{1}=\mathbb{S}{2}S1=S2 if and only if dim S1=dimS2\mathbb{S}{1}= \text{dim}\mathbb{S}{2}S1=dimS2. Warning: Pay attention to the hypothesis S1⊆S2\mathbb{S}{1}\subseteq\mathbb{S}{2}S1⊆S2. Without it, it is not true that S1=S2\mathbb{S}{1}=\mathbb{S}{2}S1=S2 if dim S1=dimS2.\mathbb{S}{1}=\text{dim}\mathbb{S}{2}.S1=dimS2.

5.2 Coordinates

Without considering other possibilities, we have learned about R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2 and its coordinates with the standard basis {e⃗1,e⃗2}\{\vec{e}_{1},\vec{e}_{2}\}{e1​,e2​} as the "natural language". Could we possibly use another system to represent coordinates for points in R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2? Yes! Consider that in Atlantis their standard grid for R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2 is formed from the vectors [11]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}[11​] and [1−1]\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}[1−1​] as seen in the picture below. In this scenario, what would be the coordinates for the point A?

Theorem 5.2.1

If B={v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}B={v1​,...,vk​} is a basis for a subspace S of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn, then every v⃗∈S\vec{v}\in\mathbb{S}v∈S can be written as a unique linear combination of the vectors in B.

Let B={v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}{1},...,\vec{v}{k}\}B={v1,...,vk} be a basis for a subspace S of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn. If v⃗=b1v⃗1+⋅⋅⋅+bkv⃗k\vec{v}=b_{1}\vec{v}_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{k}\vec{v}_{k}v=b1​v1​+⋅⋅⋅+bk​vk​ then b1,...,bkb_{1},...,b_{k}b1​,...,bk​ are called the B-coordinates of v⃗\vec{v}v, and we define the B-coordinate vector (also called the coordinate vector of v⃗\vec{v}v with respect to B) by [v⃗]B=[b1⋮bk][\vec{v}]{\mathcal{B}}=\begin{bmatrix}b{1}\\ \vdots\\ b_{k}\end{bmatrix}[v]B=​b1⋮bk​​​

Remark

It is important to notice that the coordinates of a vector are dependent on which basis is being used. Moreover, it is also dependent on the order of vectors in the basis. Thus, to prevent confusion, when we speak of a basis, we mean an ordered basis. For example, {[10],[01]}\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 0\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}0\\ 1\end{matrix}]\}{[10​],[01​]} and {[01],[10]}\{[\begin{matrix}0\\ 1\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}1\\ 0\end{matrix}]\}{[01​],[10​]} are different ordered bases for R2\mathbb{R}^{2}R2, even though they are equal as sets.

Theorem 5.2.10

If S is a subspace of Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn with basis B={v⃗1,...,v⃗k}\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}_{1},...,\vec{v}_{k}\}B={v1​,...,vk​}, then for any v⃗,w⃗∈S\vec{v}, \vec{w}\in\mathbb{S}v,w∈S and s, t∈Rt\in\mathbb{R}t∈R we have [sv⃗+tw⃗]B=s[v⃗]B+t[w⃗]B[s\vec{v}+t\vec{w}]{\mathcal{B}}=s[\vec{v}]{\mathcal{B}}+t[\vec{w}]_{\mathcal{B}}[sv+tw]B=s[v]B+t[w]B​

e.g. Let B={[11],[1−1]}\mathcal{B}=\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 1\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}1\\ -1\end{matrix}]\}B={[11​],[1−1​]} and C={[11],[0−1]}\mathcal{C}=\{[\begin{matrix}1\\ 1\end{matrix}],[\begin{matrix}0\\ -1\end{matrix}]\}C={[11​],[0−1​]}. Given that [x⃗]B=[25][\vec{x}]{\mathcal{B}}=\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 5\end{bmatrix}[x]B=[25​], determine [x⃗]C[\vec{x}]{\mathcal{C}}[x]C. x⃗=2[11]+5[1−1]=[22]+[5−5]=[7−3]\vec{x} = 2\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix} + 5\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}2\\2\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}5\\-5\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}7\\-3\end{bmatrix}x=2[11​]+5[1−1​]=[22​]+[5−5​]=[7−3​]. Now we want to find c1,c2c_1, c_2c1​,c2​ such that [7−3]=c1[11]+c2[0−1]\begin{bmatrix}7\\-3\end{bmatrix} = c_1\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix} + c_2\begin{bmatrix}0\\-1\end{bmatrix}[7−3​]=c1​[11​]+c2​[0−1​]. c1=7c_1 = 7c1​=7. c1−c2=−3⇒7−c2=−3⇒c2=10c_1 - c_2 = -3 \Rightarrow 7 - c_2 = -3 \Rightarrow c_2 = 10c1​−c2​=−3⇒7−c2​=−3⇒c2​=10. So, [x⃗]C=[710][\vec{x}]{\mathcal{C}} = \begin{bmatrix}7\\10\end{bmatrix}[x]C=[710​]. [x⃗]C=[2[11]+5[1−1]]C=2[[11]]C+5[[1−1]]C[\vec{x}]{\mathcal{C}} = [2\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix} + 5\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}} = 2[\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}} + 5[\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}}[x]C=[2[11​]+5[1−1​]]C=2[[11​]]C+5[[1−1​]]C. To find [11]C[\begin{smallmatrix}1\\1\end{smallmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}}[11​]C: c1[11]+c2[0−1]=[11]⇒c1=1,c1−c2=1⇒1−c2=1⇒c2=0c_1\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix} + c_2\begin{bmatrix}0\\-1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix} \Rightarrow c_1=1, c_1-c_2=1 \Rightarrow 1-c_2=1 \Rightarrow c_2=0c1​[11​]+c2​[0−1​]=[11​]⇒c1​=1,c1​−c2​=1⇒1−c2​=1⇒c2​=0. So [11]C=[10][\begin{smallmatrix}1\\1\end{smallmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}} = \begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}[11​]C=[10​]. To find [1−1]C[\begin{smallmatrix}1\\-1\end{smallmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}}[1−1​]C: c1[11]+c2[0−1]=[1−1]⇒c1=1,c1−c2=−1⇒1−c2=−1⇒c2=2c_1\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\end{bmatrix} + c_2\begin{bmatrix}0\\-1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1\\-1\end{bmatrix} \Rightarrow c_1=1, c_1-c_2=-1 \Rightarrow 1-c_2=-1 \Rightarrow c_2=2c1​[11​]+c2​[0−1​]=[1−1​]⇒c1​=1,c1​−c2​=−1⇒1−c2​=−1⇒c2​=2. If we now had to repeat the process for y⃗\vec{y}y​ such that [y⃗]B=[4−2][\vec{y}]{\mathcal{B}}=\begin{bmatrix}4\\ -2\end{bmatrix}[y​]B=[4−2​], we would have [y⃗]C=[4[11]−2[1−1]]C=4[[11]]C−2[[1−1]]C[\vec{y}]{\mathcal{C}}=[4\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}-2\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}}=4[\begin{bmatrix}1\\ 1\end{bmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}}-2[\begin{bmatrix}1\\ -1\end{bmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}}[y​]C=[4[11​]−2[1−1​]]C=4[[11​]]C−2[[1−1​]]C that is, using the matrix-vector multiplication notation [y⃗]C=[[11]C[1−1]C][4−2]=[1102][4−2]=[4−20−4]=[2−4][\vec{y}]{\mathcal{C}}=\begin{bmatrix}[\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ 1\end{smallmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}}&[\begin{smallmatrix}1\\ -1\end{smallmatrix}]{\mathcal{C}}\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}4\\ -2\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}1&1\\ 0&2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}4\\ -2\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}4-2\\0-4\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}2\\-4\end{bmatrix}[y​]C=[[11​]C​[1−1​]C​][4−2​]=[10​12​][4−2​]=[4−20−4​]=[2−4​]

(converter B→C\mathcal{B}\rightarrow \mathcal{C}B→C)

Theorem 5.2.16

If B\mathcal{B}B and C\mathcal{C}C are bases for a k-dimensional subspace S, then the change of coordinate matrices CPB{}{\mathcal{C}}P{\mathcal{B}}CPB and BPC{}{\mathcal{B}}P{\mathcal{C}}BPC satisfy CPBBPC=IandBPCCPB=I.{}{\mathcal{C}}P{\mathcal{B}} {}{\mathcal{B}}P{\mathcal{C}}=I \quad \text{and} \quad {}{\mathcal{B}}P{\mathcal{C}} {}{\mathcal{C}}P{\mathcal{B}}=I.CPBBPC=IandBPCCPB=I.
